lines.text: There's a name for you ladies, but it isn't used in high society... outside of a kennel. So long, ladies!
I've had two years to grow claws mother. Jungle red.
Get me a bromide - and put some gin in it.
Oh, you remember the awful things they said about what's-her-name before she jumped out the window? There. You see? I can't even remember her name so who cares?
You're passing up a swell chance, honey. Where I spit no grass grows ever.
You just can't bear Mary's happiness, can you, Sylvia? It gets you down.
How ridiculous! Why should it?
Because she's contented. Contented to be what she is.
Which is what?
A woman.
Ah! And what are we?
Females.
Really. And what are you, pet?
I'm an old maid, a frozen asset.
Well, heaven be praised, I'm on to my husband, I wouldn't trust him on Alcatraz, the mouse.
Sylvia, you oughtn't talk about him like that! Why, I think it's disloyal!
Oh now, listen Peggy, do we know how the men talk about us when we're not around?
I've heard rumours.
Exactly... And uh... While we're on the subject, have either of you wondered whether the master of this maison might not be straying?
I haven't.
Well, for all you know Mary Haines may be living in a fool's paradise.
You're so resourceful darling. I ought to go to you for plots.
You ought to go to *someone*.

[Regarding men]
You can't trust none of 'em no further than I can kick this lemon pie.
Well, cheer up, Mary; living alone has its compensations. Heaven knows it's marvelous being able to spread out in bed like a swastika.
You know, the first man that can think up a good explanation how he can be in love with his wife and another woman is gonna win that prize they're always giving out in Sweden.
Mrs. Haines never listens to any of her friends...

[under her breath]
How does she avoid it?
Arms flat. Crawl slowly up the wall...
The way you say that makes me feel like vermin.
That shouldn't be much effort. I mean, crawling up the wall.
It will be out tomorrow, Mrs. Prowler.

[Turns around and gives her the evils]
FOWLER!

[Smiling sarcastically]
Oh I'm so sorry...
[corrects herself]
Mrs. Fowler.

[Wiping her hands on towel]
Oh, cheap Chinese embroidery! You know, I'll bet Peggy gave her these...
It wouldn't be so bad if only Mary's friends knew; we could keep our mouths shut.
I know plenty I'd never breathe about my friend's husbands.
Oh, so do I!
[They both turn around and look at each other]
Well, you know, I adore Mary!
I worship her! We're not only cousins; she's my dearest friend in the world. After all, we were raised together!
[Turns around quickly]
Oh Edith, I forgot to tell you...
[Whispers to Edith]
Break it up, girls! Break it up!
Darling!
Hello!
You're so slim, I could kill you.
You don't have to. The diet I'm on is pure poison.

[Holding up a bottle of Summer Rain perfume]
A friend of ours, Mrs. Stephen Haines, simply dotes on this.
Really!
Her husband picked it out for her. Perhaps you sold it to him. Stephen Haines, the engineer?
Oh, I'm afraid I don't remember. You see, we have so many men come in here.
Awfully good-looking. Tall, fair, distinguished. I'm sure you wouldn't overlook him.
I'm sorry, but when one's mind is on one's own business...
Of course. And, as you say, you have so many men.
May I suggest, if you're dressing to please Stephen, not that one. He doesn't like such obvious effects.
Thanks for the tip. But when anything I wear doesn't please Stephen, I take it off.
I'm having him dine at my place. It's about time he found out I was a home girl.
A home girl? Get her! Why don't you borrow the quintuplets for the evening?
Because I'm all the baby he wants, pet.
Mrs. Fowler you've hardly moved a muscle.
Whose carcass is this, yours or mine?
It's yours, but I'm paid to exercise it.
You sound like a horse trainer.
No, Mrs. Fowler, but you're getting warm.
Will I find anything in that ice box of yours?
Yeah, cobwebs and a bottle of gin.

[to Sylvia, about Sylvia's husband]
I made him pay for what he wanted... you made him pay for what he didn't want.

[to Miriam]
Why you...!

[At the place Crystal Allen works]
Well, here we are... Creeping up on her!
Darling do you think we ought to do this?
Oh shut up!

[Spots lady]
That's little Crystal!
None other...

[Turns around]
May I serve you madam?

[Surprised]
No, thank you!

[Surprised]
Just looking!
[Walking away]
Oh from the neck up I'd say no...
[Spots other woman]
Ah, how about baby?
Of course!
[Walks over to her]
Mmmm... Couldn't be anyone else!
[Hears other lady call her "Pat"]
Pat?
I still don't know why he overlooked her.
I do...
[points to Crystal]
Pipe.

[about Slyvia and the model arguing]
Oh it's just professional jealousy, they're really very good friends!
Of course! She adores the Fowler family. Particularly my husband.
Are you accusing me of flirting with Howard?
No, my little pet, but of trying to! I'd like to see Howard bat an eye at another woman!
Well I've seen him, and she's not bad either!
Did you get her innuendo?
This sweet thing is getting her first divorce too! She's a very dear friend of mine... What did you say your name was again darling?
Miriam Aarons.

[Introducing Mary and Miriam]
This is Mrs. Haines. You know, yanked the scalp off that Allen woman in the fitting room?
Oh yeah! Good for you! I was afraid you were a wet firecracker, sister. Shake!
Oh, I wish I could make a little money writing the way you do!
If you wrote the way I do, that's just what you'd make.
You're not a very popular author, are you, dear?
Not with you.

[Showing her nails to Mary]
Mary, how do you like that?
Too, too adorable.
Ah, you have no idea how it stays on... I get it at Sydney's. You should go, Mary. A wonderful new manicurist. Olga's her name; she's marvelous. Isn't that divine? Jungle Red!
Looks like you've been tearing at somebody's throat!

[Smacks her hand on the table]
I'll be darned, Nancy, if I'll let you ride me anymore!
Oh Sylvia, Nancy's only trying to be clever, too.
Well, she takes a crack at everything about me... Even my nails!
Well, I like them, I really do. Sydney's, Olga's, Jungle Red... I'll remember.
You know I go to Sydney's for my hair. Oh, you ought to go, pet. I DESPISE whoever does yours.
What are you going to write next, Nancy? Animal stories?

[looking at Sylvia Fowler]
I wouldn't have to go to Africa for that.
Any ladle's sweet that dishes out some gravy.
I saw Mrs. Potter at the zoo that day.
Who was she visiting with? The snakes?
Oh, Mother!
As a matter of fact, she was!

I never got a sou out of anybody except my first husband, Mr. Strauss. Oh he said the most touching thing in his will, I remember every word of it... He said "To my beloved wife Flora, I leave all my estate... To be administered by executors because she is an A-1 schlemiel."
[Sarcastically]
Isn't that sweet?

[about Buck Winston]
Well he could crack a coconut with those knees!... If he could get them together!

[to "Gillingswater"]
You don't look a day over 35!
[walks into room]
That old gasoline truck, she's 60 if she's a minute.
Who is she?
Gillingswater.
Oh, that old bag! One more permanent and she won't have a hair on her head.

[taking a puff out of her cigarette]
She's got plenty on her arms baby!
She sure does shed, don't she!

[to Countess DeLave]
Chin up.
Right, both of them.
What are you, pet?
What nature abhors. I am an old maid, a frozen asset.
She's got those eyes that run up and down a man like a searchlight.
If you throw a lambchop into a hot oven, what's gonna keep it from gettin' done?
A woman's compromised the day she's born.
You should have licked that girl where she licked you; in his arms. It's where you win in the first round and if I know men, it's still Custer's Last Stand.
I'd die before I hurt Edith.

[offering Sylvia a tray of nuts]
Nuts.
Is that anyway to talk to me, after all I've done for you?
Aw, done what?
You didn't know a soul when you married Steven. After all, it wasn't easy to put you over.
And who said you put me over?
I've gotten you into some of our very best homes.

[in a Ritzy tone]
Yes, for some of their very best insults!
Our new one-piece lace foundation garment. Zips up the back and no bone.

[instructing Mrs. Fowler in her exercises]
Up, over. Up, down. Up, stretch! Up, together.
No more up. This has got me down.
Rest a moment and relax your diaphragm muscles.
[under her breath]
If you can.
Let's begin with posture. A lady always enters a room erect.
Most of my friends exit horizontally.
Oh, the publicity! La publicité!

[Opens the door for Edith]
How do you do, Mrs. Potter?
Hello, Jane.
And how are you feeling today?
Too awful. I wouldn't wish my woes on my worst friend.
[Looks around the corner]
Oh Jane, will you tell Mrs. Fowler that I'd like to speak to her out here for just a moment.
Yes, Mrs. Potter.

[Comes around the corner and surprises Edith]
How's the little mother?

[shouts out to Jane]
Jane! Never mind about that...
[to Nancy]
Hello, dear...
The spider's in the parlor. Let's go join her.

[In tub]
Holy mackerel!
[Sarcastically]
What a cheerful evening! Oh, I'm so bored!
[Throws sponge and almost hits maid]

[Surprised]
Monsieur says that it doesn't improve madame's nerves to stay so long in ze water.
What'd he mean by that? A crack?
Oh... No he did not say is zat way madame.

[Smirks]
I thought not... I've been Mrs. Stephen Haines for 18 months now without a single squawk.
[laughs softly]
That's some sort of a record for Park Avenue!
[phone rings - says to maid]
Get out.
[Loudly and impatiently]
Get OUT! Go on! Go on!

[On the train]
Listen to the wheels, don't they seem to be saying something?

[Softly]
No.
Don't they seem to be saying... Go back, go back, go back, go back?
Mommy, will daddy come to Reno?
No, darling.
Mommy, where is daddy?
I don't know and I don't care. In the future you'll please refer to him as "That heel"!
But whither... Whither shall I fly?
To the arms our our pet cowboy, darling!

[Gasps]
Miriam Aarons!
Why, he's plum loco for you, countess! He likes you even better than his horse! And it's such a blasted big horse, too!
Weren't you going to Africa to shoot, Nancy?
As soon as my book's out.
I don't blame you. I'd rather face a tiger any day than the sort of things the critics said about your last book.
I'm devoted to Edith Potter, but she DOES get me down...
I don't need to sit around and act glum. When I think of what I've sacrificed for Howard Fowler!
Such as what, Mrs. Fowler?

[Looks at Miriam]
I gave him my youth!

[Introduces them]
This is the Countess DeLave... Mrs. Howard Fowler.

[Same time]
How do you do?

[Same time]
How do you do?
And Miriam Aarons.
How do you do?

[Looks closely at Miriam's flat chest]
How do *you* do?

[while giving Mary a manicure]
Well this Crystal Allen is a friend of mine, she's really a terrible man trap, soak it please. She's behind the perfume counter at Black's, so was I before I got fired... Uh, left.
I think I got what Mrs. Fowler's friends come in for.

[Last lines]
Mary Haines, don't you have any pride?
No pride at all. That's a luxury a woman in love can't afford.

[gasp]
Good grief! I hate to tell you, dear, but your skin makes the Rocky Mountains look like chiffon velvet!

[looking at Sylvia Fowler's blouse]
Great guns. What are you made up for? The Seeing Eye?
He beats you. Lucy, how terrible.
Ain't it. When you think of the lot of women on this ranch who need a beatin' more than I do.
So he says 'I gotta go home on Sunday.' So I says 'Why do you got to?' So he says 'they always expect me home on Easter Sunday.' So I say, 'what do they expect you to do? Lay an egg?'"
I'll be doing the cooking so you know what he'll get.
I know - indigestion.
Oh, l'amour, l'amour, how it can let you down. Hmm. How it can pick you up again.
Them big, strong, red-headed men... they're fierce!
Say, listen, I've worked too hard to land this meal ticket to make any false moves now.
Why you sly little fox, you.
Oh, poor creatures. They've lost their equilibrium because they've lost their faith in love. Oh l'amour, l'amour.
Now don't that sound just like a husband?
Oh, she can't help it. It's just her tough luck that she wasn't born deaf and dumb.
Listen, sister, when are you going to get wise to yourself?
Did you get her innuendo?
You noble wives and mothers bore the brains out of me. And I bet you bore your husbands, too.
You are a hard one.
I can be soft on the right occasion.
I still say I'm gonna pull a gun on that guy. Just like I did on Judge McClure.
"What do you do with yourself all day Mrs. Fowler?"
You can't trust any man. That's all they want!

[innocently]
What else have we got to give?
One minute more, Mrs. Miller and you can breathe again.

[barging in]
Oh, I'm sorry. I'm looking for grandma.
[she wanders into the next room]
Grandma isn't in there...
Well, she isn't in here... Oh! This tub has worms in it! I know it has worms! I can feel them!
They're probably more afraid of you than you are of them.
Well, what's the matter with a little worm? Why, at Harvard and Yale they eat them...

[singing]
If the ocean was whiskey, and I was a duck, I'd dive to the bottom, and never come up. Oh baby, oh baby, I've told you before, the more I drink whiskey, I love you the more! Oh baby, oh ba...
[gets cut off]

[Walks through the door]
Oh, l'amour, l'amour!
I don't understand grownups on the telephone. They all sound silly.
Stephen is a man. He's been married ten years.
Oh. You mean he's tired of me?
Stephen's tired of himself. Tired of feeling the same things in himself. Time comes when a man's got to feel something new, and he's got to feel young again, just because he's growing old.
Mother! Stephen isn't old!
to see a different self in the mirror of some woman's eyes.
Oh uh... is that umm... Crystal Allen across the hall?
Yes she's a new customer. Do you know her? Has she a lot of money?
I think she knows where she can get a lot.

[answering phone]
Hello? Oh, hello, Stephen.
[surprised]
What? Well uh... Don't worry, my sweet, I... Of course, I don't mind your breaking our engagement! Well, that is, I mind, of course, but it's such good discipline for my selfishness about you.
Holy mackerel, what a line!

[to Pat]
Shut up, will ya?

[to Stephen]
Well, I, uh... I was going to surprise you tonight, darling, and... and cook dinner myself in my little apartment.
[laughs]
Why, of course I can cook!
She thinks because Lulu's dark, he wont be able to see her!

[to Pat]
Shhh!

[to Stephen]
Oh, well, you don't know half my accomplishments...
I'll say he doesn't!

[to Pat]
Will you get out of here?

[to Stephen]
Oh... Oh, well, that's all right, Stephen; I'll save you a piece of the cake... with a candle on it. Ah, well, I didn't want to tell you before, Stephen, because I was afraid you might do something extravagant! Oh, it is dear of you to want to be with me on my birthday, but... I won't be lonely. No, honestly, I won't. And uh... if this weather lets up, my neuralgia will be better...
[shaky voiced]
then maybe I can... Oh no! It's nothing. It's just nerves. I had a rather gloomy letter from home today. My little sister, she's not very well...
What's wrong with her? She got a hangover?

[ignoring Pat]
But she'll be all right. Yes, I... I'm holding the thought. Oh, no, Stephen! I couldn't think of your disarranging your evening! I'll have another birthday next year!
You'll have another one next week!

[to Pat]
Look, so help me, I'm gonna slug you!

[to Stephen]
Oh, Stephen, if you could drop by for just a few moments and have a glass of sherry to my health. Oh, Stephen... Oh, I do need you so... Yes, dear... Yes, darling, I'll meet you on our corner in five minutes!
[sends kisses into the phone]
Goodbye!
[hangs up]

[to Pat]
Say, can you beat him? He almost stood me up for his wife!
Mary, you're not cross because my Buck's had a wee droppy too much?
Don't be modest, Flora. Your ducky is stinko!

[sitting on Sylvia Fowler]
Take it easy, Mrs. Fowler. I'm only trying to help in my own way.
Oh, you big moose!
Besides, there's nothing like a good dose of being left alone to make a man appreciate his wife.
I'm an old woman, my dear. I know my sex.
Ooh, look at Sidney's miniatures.
Hmmm. Sure sign of a petty mind!
They've been waiting half and hour, Mrs. Spencer. Would you mind seeing the art exhibit later?
All right.
[to her friend]
Art exhibit my foot!
